importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, marking the latest update on the Reefline project's progress and public awareness, signaling its ongoing development and relevance in environmental and cultural discourse.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with initial installations launching in 2025 and full realization anticipated by 2035, aligning with long-term ecological restoration and sustainable tourism goals.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a seven-mile-long artificial reef off Miami Beach, designed as both an ecological restoration and an underwater art installation.
The project includes 22 concrete cars cast into underwater formations that serve as coral substrates, eventually being overtaken by growing coral.
The reef will be accessible to the public via swimming at depths of 15 to 20 feet, 700 feet off Miami Beach, requiring only a mask and fins.
The project is a collaboration between artist Ximena Caminos and marine scientist Colin Foord, integrating art, science, and environmental restoration.
Reefline aims to restore a historic coral reef that was lost to beach sand replenishment in the 1970s.
Local resilient corals are being used to withstand rising ocean temperatures and disease, ensuring long-term sustainability.
The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks an additional $6 million through public fundraising.
A marine learning center will be established onshore to educate the public about endangered coral reefs.
Future phases include 57 giant sculpted starfish, which may become a cultural symbol of Miami Beach.
The project reflects a broader trend of using art to foster ecological awareness and sustainable tourism.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a seven-mile-long artificial reef off its coast, combining marine science and art to restore a historic coral habitat lost in the 1970s. Led by marine biologist Colin Foord and arts curator Ximena Caminos, the project includes 22 concrete cars arranged in an underwater traffic jam that will serve as coral substrates, eventually being covered by growing gorgonian and other soft corals. Designed as both an ecological restoration and an underwater tourist attraction, Reefline is accessible to the public via swimming at shallow depths and aims to bring back a natural marine ecosystem that once existed in the area. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks $6 million in additional public funding, with a marine learning center planned to educate visitors. A future phase involving 57 giant starfish sculptures may one day become a cultural symbol of the city, reflecting the broader mission of using art to revitalize communities and protect the environment.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
